transcript:
Patient: I appreciate your confidence in me, Nova. It means a lot to know that you believe in my ability to keep making progress.

Therapist: I absolutely believe in you, Mariana. You've demonstrated remarkable resilience and dedication throughout our work together. As we wrap up our final session, I want to emphasize that the skills you've learned are yours to keep and use whenever you need them. You have the power to continue nurturing your mental health and well-being.

Patient: Thank you for all your guidance and support, Nova. I feel more equipped to handle life's challenges now. It's been a difficult journey, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made.

Therapist: You're welcome, Mariana. It's been an honor to work with you and witness your growth. Remember, progress isn't always linear – there will be ups and downs, but you have the tools to navigate those challenges. Before we end our session, let's discuss your homework for the coming weeks.

Patient: Okay, I'm ready.

Therapist: For your homework, I'd like you to continue practicing the skills we've discussed, such as using thought records, engaging in behavioral activation, and referring to your coping cards when needed. Additionally, I encourage you to reach out to your support system regularly, even if it's just a quick check-in. Prioritize self-care activities that nourish your mind, body, and soul, like spending time with the animals at the shelter or engaging in hobbies you enjoy. Finally, pay attention to any early warning signs of depression and implement your relapse prevention plan if needed. How does that sound?

Patient: That sounds manageable. I'll make sure to keep practicing the skills and prioritizing self-care. I know it won't always be easy, but I'm committed to maintaining my progress.

Therapist: That's fantastic, Mariana. Remember, you don't have to do this alone. Lean on your support system, and don't hesitate to reach out for professional help if you feel you need additional support in the future. You've got this!

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I feel more prepared now. I know there will be challenges ahead, but I'm ready to face them with the tools I've learned.

Therapist: You are ready, Mariana. I have complete faith in your ability to continue thriving. If you ever find yourself struggling, remember to refer back to your CBT toolbox and coping cards. They will always be there to guide you. I'm so proud of the work you've done, and I'm excited to see how you continue to grow and flourish in the future.

Patient: Your words mean so much to me, Nova. Thank you for being such a wonderful support throughout this journey. I'm grateful for everything I've learned in therapy.

Therapist: It's been my pleasure, Mariana. Before we end our session, I want to provide you with a detailed summary of our work together. Here's your session summary:

Session Summary:
- Main topics discussed: Reviewing progress made in therapy, discussing ongoing support and self-care plans, reinforcing CBT skills and techniques, and celebrating Mariana's growth and accomplishments.
- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Review of CBT skills learned (thought records, self-care plan, behavioral activation, etc.)
  - Problem-solving future challenges using CBT techniques
  - Creating a personalized CBT toolbox
  - Developing a relapse prevention plan, including identifying early warning signs and strategies to cope
  - Introducing coping cards with adaptive thoughts, strategies, and new core beliefs
  - Progress: Mariana has made significant progress in understanding and applying CBT concepts, developing a more balanced perspective on her thoughts and beliefs, and prioritizing her mental health and self-care. She is feeling more confident in her ability to use CBT skills independently, although she acknowledges that setbacks and challenges may still arise.
- Homework assigned: Continue practicing CBT skills (thought records, behavioral activation, coping cards), reach out to support system regularly, prioritize self-care activities, and pay attention to early warning signs and implement relapse prevention plan if needed.
- Patient's progress, challenges, depression symptoms and important personal details: Mariana is feeling proud of her progress but also nervous about ending therapy. She has identified potential early warning signs of worsening depression symptoms and has developed strategies to cope with them, including reaching out to her support system and engaging in self-care activities.
- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs: Mariana has been working on challenging her core belief of not being good enough and her intermediate belief that she should be able to handle everything on her own. She has developed more adaptive beliefs, such as "I am resilient and capable" and "Asking for help is a sign of strength."
- Important information to carry forward: Mariana's personalized CBT toolbox and coping cards, her relapse prevention plan, and her ongoing progress in challenging negative thoughts and beliefs.
- Plan for the next session: As this is our final session, there is no plan for a future session. Mariana will continue to use the skills and tools she's learned in therapy to maintain her progress and manage any future challenges that may arise.
